docs.abstract: New York Knickerbockers defeat Indiana Pacers, 87-73; photos (M)2

headline.main: With a Big Flop, Childs Is a Star For the Knicks

docs.lead_paragraph: It was just the cellophane-thin Reggie Miller, but upon the slightest contact, Chris Childs's upper body suddenly and violently buckled out like a question mark, his head snapped back and he hit the floor in a heap. A whistle cut in, and a foul was called on . . . Miller. As the Madison Square Garden crowd mocked its favorite foil from Indiana, Childs bounced to his feet and all but cried out, ''Makeup!'' He had just out-acted one of the greatest flops on Broadway, just upstaged the theatrical Miller.

docs.abstract: Status of injured New Jersey Nets forward Jayson Williams discussed (M)

headline.main: Williams And Nets May Hurry His Return

docs.lead_paragraph: Throughout the season, Jayson Williams has joked about the Nets' feelings toward him. During the rough times, Williams says, team officials nag him to return from the knee and broken leg injuries that have kept him sidelined since last April. But when the team prospered in December, Williams said they urged him to take his time and perhaps wait until next season to play. Now, of course, is a rough time, and Coach Don Casey, his Nets having lost eight of their last 10 games, is practically imploring Williams to get back on the court as soon as possible. Williams provided Casey with a small degree of hope today by disclosing that his surgically repaired right leg is at least 60 percent as strong as his left leg.

docs.abstract: Toronto Raptors defeat New York Knickerbockers, 91-70; photo (M)

headline.main: Knicks Have No Match For the Magic of Carter

docs.lead_paragraph: All the grim-faced starters finished the fourth quarter sitting on the bench, staring at a game that seemed like a reflection in a fun-house mirror. This was too distorted to be happening, too exaggerated to be real. But this is what the presence of the Raptors' Vince Carter can do to a team that was as ill prepared to play as the Knicks were tonight. He simply made them surrender.

docs.abstract: Connecticut defeats Seton Hall, 59-50, in college basketball; photo (M)

headline.main: Huskies Find Old Form to Stop Surging Pirates

docs.lead_paragraph: For seven minutes at least, the Connecticut Huskies looked tonight like the team of last season that often stitched vivid sequences together into a deep, textured blanket of basketball. That kind of play kept Huskies Coach Jim Calhoun comfortable, and it knitted up perfectly to a national championship to warm fans in a hoops-crazy state. You couldn't blame the rabid UConn fans if they reached for that basketball linen closet in the second half tonight against Seton Hall when the Huskies went on a 15-1 run. It brought back those memories at a time when there appeared to be a thread pulling loose.

docs.abstract: Basketball game between New York Knickerbockers and Washington Wizards in Washington, DC, is postponed because of snow (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Knicks flew down to Washington late Monday night, after defeating the Seattle SuperSonics at Madison Square Garden, to prepare for last night's game against the Wizards. They then took a train back to New York yesterday afternoon after a snowstorm that blanketed the East Coast led to the cancellation of the game. The meeting with the Wizards would have been the Knicks' first chance to meet up with Michael Jordan in his new role as head of basketball operations for Washington.

docs.abstract: Miami defeats Seton Hall, 71-64, in college basketball; photo (M)

headline.main: Miami Finally Lives Up to Expectations

docs.lead_paragraph: Miami needed to win its first conference road game to halt the disappointing start to its season. The Hurricanes used strong defense and solid free-throw shooting for a 71-64 victory over Seton Hall tonight. The victory snapped the Pirates' seven-game winning streak and gave Miami a chance to hang on to some lofty preseason expectations.

docs.abstract: Stony Brook women's basketball team, which moved up to Division 1 this year, is outperforming expectations on steady shooting of freshman guard Julie Szabo; she comments, interview; photo (M)

headline.main: Szabo and Stony Brook Shoot for the Big Time

docs.lead_paragraph: Teams that move up to Division I are supposed to be bad. They are supposed to do poorly until a few recruiting classes pass through and elevate the program into respectability. But not the Stony Brook women's basketball team. Winners of 9 of their last 10 games heading into today's game at home against Navy, the Seawolves (9-4) have been defying expectations on the steady shooting of the freshman guard Julie Szabo, the nation's eighth-leading scorer at 22.3 points a game.

docs.abstract: On Basketball column discusses strained relationship between Philadelphia 76ers coach Larry Brown and player Allen Iverson; photo (M)

headline.main: Iverson Haunts Brown, Even Across the Pacific

docs.lead_paragraph: Larry Brown was reminiscing recently about a much simpler time in international competition, when an Olympic basketball player for the United States had no one to carry his bags during training camp in Hawaii, when you could not order coconut shrimp as an appetizer. ''Nobody in '64 had ever been to Hawaii that I know of,'' said Brown, an assistant coach with the 2000 team and in 1964 a point guard for Hank Iba's Olympic team that played in Tokyo, which also featured Bill Bradley, Walt Hazzard and Jim Barnes.

docs.abstract: Portland Trail Blazers player Brian Grant visits New York for meeting with New York Knickerbockers coach Jeff Van Gundy and general manager Scott Layden, who are anxious to recruit him (M)

headline.main: Grant to Give New York a Look

docs.lead_paragraph: Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy and General Manager Scott Layden stood nervously by the window at Gate 92 in Newark Airport, talking on cell phones and watching for the flight from Portland, Ore., to arrive. When the plane pulled up to the gate and Brian Grant disembarked, it marked the start of the Knicks' biggest recruiting opportunity and a chance to again alter their aging team. With Larry Johnson's body wearing down, the Knicks can offer the 6-foot-9-inch Grant a starting job at power forward and the money that he seeks if he were to commit to New York and force a sign-and-trade deal with the Portland Trail Blazers.

docs.abstract: Matt Doherty steps down as Notre Dame head coach to coach University of North Carolina basketball team, ending search for Bill Guthridge's replacement; decision follows call from former North Carolina teammate Michael Jordan (M)

headline.main: Tar Heels Pass On The Mantle To Doherty

docs.lead_paragraph: Matt Doherty received a telephone call early this morning. It was Michael Jordan, who told his former University of North Carolina teammate to follow his heart. Doherty, a starter on North Carolina's 1982 National Collegiate Athletic Association national championship team, took Jordan's advice and stepped down as head coach at Notre Dame after one season to become coach of one of the more successful college basketball programs in the country, ending a 12-day search for Bill Guthridge's replacement.
